quotes: Hawthorn West Central School (1950–57);
Melbourne High School, where he was school captain (1958–61);
the University of Melbourne (1962–67) where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Laws with First-Class Honours,
President of the Students Representative Council from 1964 to 1966;
Magdalen College, Oxford (1968–70), where he attended on a Shell scholarship and graduated with a Master of Arts with First-Class Honours in Philosophy, Politics and Economics (PPE).
In 2004, he was elected an Honorary Fellow of Magdalen College, his alma mater at Oxford.
From 1971 to 1976, he was law academic at the University of Melbourne, teaching crime, torts, civil liberties law and federal constitutional law,
especially at the time of the dismissal of the Whitlam Government in 1975.
In 1977 he edited Labor and the Constitution 1972–75, a collection of essays on constitutional issues arising during the life of the Whitlam government,

time_markers.text: From 1976 to his entry into the Parliament
quotes: From 1976 to his entry into the Parliament he practised full-time as a barrister, specialising in industrial law, and appellate argument,
became a Queen's Counsel (in Victoria and the ACT) in 1983.
